elements.content: A multifunctional three-dimensional lanthanide metal–organic framework has been rationally constructed. Highly selective sensing of benzaldehyde and Cu2+ ions makes it a potential bifunctional sensor. Also, it could serve as a good candidate material for the removal of dyes from effluents based on the size exclusion.
elements.clean_text: A multifunctional three-dimensional lanthanide metal-organic framework has been rationally constructed. Highly selective sensing of benzaldehyde and Cu2+ ions makes it a potential bifunctional sensor. Also, it could serve as a good candidate material for the removal of dyes from effluents based on the size exclusion.

elements.content: A multifunctional europium metal−organic framework has been rationally constructed that combines selective dye molecule adsorption and luminescence sensor properties for the detection of benzaldehyde and Cu2+ ions.
elements.clean_text: A multifunctional europium metal-organic framework has been rationally constructed that combines selective dye molecule adsorption and luminescence sensor properties for the detection of benzaldehyde and Cu2+ ions.

elements.content: Usually, benzaldehyde is mainly used as a plasticizer and a solvent, but it is also used as a fragrance and flavoring in pharmaceuticals, food, cosmetics, etc. However, some studies have recently found that benzaldehyde can induce genotoxic and mutagenic effects. The presence of benzaldehyde above the normal permissible limit will not only affect people’s health but also can seriously contaminate the environment. Cu2+, the third most-abundant essential trace element in the human body, plays vital roles in the areas of environmental, biological, and chemical systems. However, both deficiency and overload of Cu2+ may cause some types of severe diseases, including hematological manifestations and Alzheimer’s, Parkinson’s, and Wilson’s diseases. Moreover, copper is also considered to be an important metal pollutant because of its extensive use in modern society. Therefore, the development of convenient, cost-effective benzaldehyde and Cu2+ detection methods is critical in terms of environmental and safety considerations. Recently, syntheses of metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) as fluorescent probes have become a hot topic in the research fields of MOFs because of their outstanding merits, such as size-controllable pores and apertures, abundant unsaturated open metal sites, and uncoordinated ends of linkers. Although many MOF-based luminescence sensor materials have been investigated so far, MOFs exhibiting dual selective sensing behavior toward benzaldehyde and Cu2+ are still rare, to our knowledge.
elements.clean_text: Usually, benzaldehyde is mainly used as a plasticizer and a solvent, but it is also used as a fragrance and flavoring in pharmaceuticals, food, cosmetics, etc. However, some studies have recently found that benzaldehyde can induce genotoxic and mutagenic effects. The presence of benzaldehyde above the normal permissible limit will not only affect people's health but also can seriously contaminate the environment. Cu2+, the third most-abundant essential trace element in the human body, plays vital roles in the areas of environmental, biological, and chemical systems. However, both deficiency and overload of Cu2+ may cause some types of severe diseases, including hematological manifestations and Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, and Wilson's diseases. Moreover, copper is also considered to be an important metal pollutant because of its extensive use in modern society. Therefore, the development of convenient, cost-effective benzaldehyde and Cu2+ detection methods is critical in terms of environmental and safety considerations. Recently, syntheses of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) as fluorescent probes have become a hot topic in the research fields of MOFs because of their outstanding merits, such as size-controllable pores and apertures, abundant unsaturated open metal sites, and uncoordinated ends of linkers. Although many MOF-based luminescence sensor materials have been investigated so far, MOFs exhibiting dual selective sensing behavior toward benzaldehyde and Cu2+ are still rare, to our knowledge.

elements.content: In addition, the adsorptive removal of toxic compounds from the environment has also been studied in related fields using MOFs. Dyes are the main sources of pollution that often cause environmental problems, even at low concentration. Hence, it is urgently necessary to detect and decrease the content of dyes to realize water purification and protection. Recently, some related reports have demonstrated that coordination polymers are effective as adsorbents for the removal of organic dye pollutants.
elements.clean_text: In addition, the adsorptive removal of toxic compounds from the environment has also been studied in related fields using MOFs. Dyes are the main sources of pollution that often cause environmental problems, even at low concentration. Hence, it is urgently necessary to detect and decrease the content of dyes to realize water purification and protection. Recently, some related reports have demonstrated that coordination polymers are effective as adsorbents for the removal of organic dye pollutants.

elements.content: In this work, we report a new europium MOF composed of lanthanide metal ions and H4abtc: {[Eu2­(abtc)1.5­(H2O)3­(DMA)]·H2O·DMA} n (1; DMA = N,N-dimethylacetamide). Most interesting, 1 is a rare example of a highly selective and sensitive luminescence probe for benzaldehyde and Cu2+. In addition, the selective adsorption of dye molecules makes 1a a highly promising porous material for size-dependent adsorbents for pollutant removal.
elements.clean_text: In this work, we report a new europium MOF composed of lanthanide metal ions and H4abtc: {[Eu2(abtc)1.5(H2O)3(DMA)]⋅H2O⋅DMA} n  (1; DMA = N,N-dimethylacetamide). Most interesting, 1 is a rare example of a highly selective and sensitive luminescence probe for benzaldehyde and Cu2+. In addition, the selective adsorption of dye molecules makes 1a a highly promising porous material for size-dependent adsorbents for pollutant removal.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction (XRD) analyses reveal that 1 crystallizes in the triclinic crystal system with the P1̅ space group and features a three-dimensional (3D) coordination framework (Table S1). The asymmetric unit of 1 contains two crystallographically unique Eu3+ ions, one and a half of the abtc4– ligand, three coordinated water molecules, one coordinated DMA molecule, one free DMA molecule, and one lattice water molecule. It is interesting to note that there are two types of Eu3+ ion environments in 1 (a). Eu1 is eight-coordinated and surrounded by five carboxylate O atoms from four different ligands and three coordinated water molecules. Eu2 is eight-coordinated and surrounded by seven O atoms from six ligands and one DMA molecule. All O–Eu–O bond angles and Eu–O bond lengths are within the expected ranges. In compound 1, abtc4– adopts different coordination modes, as shown in Scheme S1. A topological approach was employed to obtain better insight into this intricate 3D framework; such a 3D network represents a rare net topology with the Schläfli symbol of {413·62}2{414·67}2{420·614·811}­{414·6}2 (d). Removal of the guest molecules reveals that the free volume of 1 is 22.5% of the crystal volume, as calculated by PLATON analysis.
elements.clean_text: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction (XRD) analyses reveal that 1 crystallizes in the triclinic crystal system with the P1̅ space group and features a three-dimensional (3D) coordination framework (Table S1). The asymmetric unit of 1 contains two crystallographically unique Eu3+ ions, one and a half of the abtc4- ligand, three coordinated water molecules, one coordinated DMA molecule, one free DMA molecule, and one lattice water molecule. It is interesting to note that there are two types of Eu3+ ion environments in 1 (a). Eu1 is eight-coordinated and surrounded by five carboxylate O atoms from four different ligands and three coordinated water molecules. Eu2 is eight-coordinated and surrounded by seven O atoms from six ligands and one DMA molecule. All O-Eu-O bond angles and Eu-O bond lengths are within the expected ranges. In compound 1, abtc4- adopts different coordination modes, as shown in Scheme S1. A topological approach was employed to obtain better insight into this intricate 3D framework; such a 3D network represents a rare net topology with the Schläfli symbol of {413⋅62}2{414⋅67}2{420⋅614⋅811}{414⋅6}2 (d). Removal of the guest molecules reveals that the free volume of 1 is 22.5% of the crystal volume, as calculated by PLATON analysis.

elements.content: (a) Coordinated environment of the Eu3+ ion in 1. (b) View of the two-dimensional network of 1. (c) 3D framework of 1. (d) Schematic view of the topology framework of 1.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Coordinated environment of the Eu3+ ion in 1. (b) View of the two-dimensional network of 1. (c) 3D framework of 1. (d) Schematic view of the topology framework of 1.

elements.content: For 1, ligand-centered emissions in the emission spectra are detected, suggesting the relatively inefficient energy transfer from the ligand to Eu3+. The potential of the activated phases 1a toward efficient sensing of small molecules was studied in common solvents. As shown in Figure S5a, subtle peak shifts in the emission spectra can be observed with different solvents and the intensities of emission peaks are largely dependent on the solvent molecules, particularly in the case of benzaldehyde, which exhibits the most significant quenching effects relative to other solvents used in this study, even after a long time (Figure S6). Thus, the activated phase 1a is a good candidate luminescent probe for the selective detection of benzaldehyde. To evaluate the recyclability of 1a on the detection of benzaldehyde, cyclic tests were carried out. The results show that 1a can be reused even after several cycles of the sequential addition of benzaldehyde (Figure S7). Moreover, powder XRD analysis of the samples after immersion in benzaldehyde revealed that the original framework structure is retained (Figure S8). The physical intermolecular solute and solvent interaction forces play an important role in such luminescence quenching processes. Upon light excitation, there is a competition of absorption of the light source energy between the ligand and analyte. After the addition of benzaldehyde, a close contact and O–H···O hydrogen bonds between the benzaldehyde and 1a may lead to the energy absorbed by the ligand being transferred to the benzaldehyde, triggering the luminescence quenching phenomenon. To further investigate the quenching effect of benzaldehyde on the luminescent intensity of 1a, benzaldehyde was gradually and increasingly added to the 1a/DMF emulsion. It is obvious that the luminescence intensities of the emulsion gradually decreased with the addition of the benzaldehyde solvent (Figure S5b). The nonlinear nature of the Stern–Volmer (SV) plots of benzaldehyde can be ascribed to self-absorption or the energy-transfer process, implying that the luminescence quenching process occurred by both dynamic and static quenching.
elements.clean_text: For 1, ligand-centered emissions in the emission spectra are detected, suggesting the relatively inefficient energy transfer from the ligand to Eu3+. The potential of the activated phases 1a toward efficient sensing of small molecules was studied in common solvents. As shown in Figure S5a, subtle peak shifts in the emission spectra can be observed with different solvents and the intensities of emission peaks are largely dependent on the solvent molecules, particularly in the case of benzaldehyde, which exhibits the most significant quenching effects relative to other solvents used in this study, even after a long time (Figure S6). Thus, the activated phase 1a is a good candidate luminescent probe for the selective detection of benzaldehyde. To evaluate the recyclability of 1a on the detection of benzaldehyde, cyclic tests were carried out. The results show that 1a can be reused even after several cycles of the sequential addition of benzaldehyde (Figure S7). Moreover, powder XRD analysis of the samples after immersion in benzaldehyde revealed that the original framework structure is retained (Figure S8). The physical intermolecular solute and solvent interaction forces play an important role in such luminescence quenching processes. Upon light excitation, there is a competition of absorption of the light source energy between the ligand and analyte. After the addition of benzaldehyde, a close contact and O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds between the benzaldehyde and 1a may lead to the energy absorbed by the ligand being transferred to the benzaldehyde, triggering the luminescence quenching phenomenon. To further investigate the quenching effect of benzaldehyde on the luminescent intensity of 1a, benzaldehyde was gradually and increasingly added to the 1a/DMF emulsion. It is obvious that the luminescence intensities of the emulsion gradually decreased with the addition of the benzaldehyde solvent (Figure S5b). The nonlinear nature of the Stern-Volmer (SV) plots of benzaldehyde can be ascribed to self-absorption or the energy-transfer process, implying that the luminescence quenching process occurred by both dynamic and static quenching.

elements.content: To explore the multifunctional applications of 1a as a luminescent probe, we further studied the ability of 1a to detect metal ions. The evacuated framework was immersed in aqueous solutions containing M­(NO3) x (M = Zn2+, Sr2+, Ba2+, Ni2+, Co2+, Pb2+, Ag+, Cu2+) and MCl2 (M = Mn2+, Fe2+). The photoluminescence properties of Mn+@1a were recorded and compared. As shown in a, the luminescence intensities of M-incorporated 1a suspensions are heavily dependent on the species of metal ions. In particular, the luminescence intensity of Cu2+-incorporated 1a is dramatically quenched compared with that of the initial 1a in water. As illustrated in Table S3, Cu2+ ions show the highest value of the quenching coefficient (529 M–1) among the studied metal ions. The value of K SV for Cu2+ in this work is comparable to or better than those of some previously reported well-designed compounds for sensing Cu2+ ions (Table S4). The remarkable and significant quenching effect by Cu2+ can be further confirmed by a photograph of the 1a suspension under UV light, as shown in the inset of b. The time-dependent luminescence of 1a and Cu2+@1a was monitored, and the results showed that the sensor can work over a long term (). The quenching effecting of Cu2+ has been further examined in different Cu­(NO3)2 solutions with concentrations in the range of 5 × 10–2–5 × 10–4 mol/L (Figure S10). The emission intensities of the samples obviously decrease as the concentration of Cu2+ ions gradually increases. The decrease of the luminescence intensity is still clearly observed when 1a is immersed in a 5 × 10–4 mol/L Cu2+ solution, and 1a shows poor emission when the concentration of Cu2+ ions increases to 0.01 M. As can be seen from c, the interference from conventional metal cations can be neglected, further convincing the high selectivity of 1a for Cu2+ detection and the potential of 1a for practical use. The recyclable experiments of sensing for Cu2+ were also investigated (Figure S11). The luminescence intensity of 1a in a Cu2+ aqueous solution after three cycles was slightly increase compared with the initial state Cu2+@1a. In addition, the release of Cu2+ from Cu2+@1a can be realized in aqueous solution (Figure S12).

The evacuated framework was immersed in aqueous solutions containing M(NO3) x  (M = Zn2+, Sr2+, Ba2+, Ni2+, Co2+, Pb2+, Ag+, Cu2+) and MCl2 (M = Mn2+, Fe2+). The photoluminescence properties of Mn+@1a were recorded and compared. As shown in a, the luminescence intensities of M-incorporated 1a suspensions are heavily dependent on the species of metal ions. In particular, the luminescence intensity of Cu2+-incorporated 1a is dramatically quenched compared with that of the initial 1a in water. The time-dependent luminescence of 1a and Cu2+@1a was monitored, and the results showed that the sensor can work over a long term (). The quenching effecting of Cu2+ has been further examined in different Cu(NO3)2 solutions with concentrations in the range of 5 × 10-2-5 × 10-4 mol/L (Figure S10). The emission intensities of the samples obviously decrease as the concentration of Cu2+ ions gradually increases. The decrease of the luminescence intensity is still clearly observed when 1a is immersed in a 5 × 10-4 mol/L Cu2+ solution, and 1a shows poor emission when the concentration of Cu2+ ions increases to 0.01 M. As can be seen from c, the interference from conventional metal cations can be neglected, further convincing the high selectivity of 1a for Cu2+ detection and the potential of 1a for practical use. The recyclable experiments of sensing for Cu2+ were also investigated (Figure S11). The luminescence intensity of 1a in a Cu2+ aqueous solution after three cycles was slightly increase compared with the initial state Cu2+@1a. In addition, the release of Cu2+ from Cu2+@1a can be realized in aqueous solution (Figure S12).

elements.content: (a) Emission spectra of 1a in diverse metal-ion aqueous solutions. (b) Comparisons of the luminescence intensity of M n+@1a. Inset: Photograph of M n+@1a under UV-light irradiation at 365 nm. (c) Luminescence intensity of 1a upon the addition of Cu2+ in the presence of a background of metal ions. (d) Color changes in the aqueous suspension of 1a with different metal ions and 1a soaked in aqueous solutions containing Cu­(NO3)2 with 10–1 and 10–2 M, respectively.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Emission spectra of 1a in diverse metal-ion aqueous solutions. (b) Comparisons of the luminescence intensity of M n+@1a. Inset: Photograph of M n+@1a under UV-light irradiation at 365 nm. (c) Luminescence intensity of 1a upon the addition of Cu2+ in the presence of a background of metal ions. (d) Color changes in the aqueous suspension of 1a with different metal ions and 1a soaked in aqueous solutions containing Cu(NO3)2 with 10-1 and 10-2 M, respectively.

elements.content: In order to understand the luminescence quenching process of 1a toward Cu2+, 1a was immersed in a M­(NO3) n or MCl2 aqueous solution to prepare the incorporated product M n+@1a. It was observed that the addition of 1a to the solutions of metal ions resulted in a visible color change of the solution for Cu2+. No such visible color change was observed upon the addition of 1a to other metal-ion solutions (d). In addition, the pictures of Cu2+@1a showed the incorporation of Cu2+ and rendered a color change of 1a from orange to green. These results indicate that 1a displays unique colors upon metal-ion encapsulation and can be considered as a universal naked-eye detector for Cu2+. The inductively coupled plasma results of the solid-state Cu2+@1a clearly indicated that the Cu2+ ion was immobilized in 1a, and the ratio of Cu and Eu for Cu2+@1a after immersion in the Cu2+ aqueous solution is 1:5.5. The corresponding energy-dispersive spectroscopy also verified the encapsulation of Cu2+ in 1a (Figure S13). The X-ray photoelectron spectrometry (XPS) spectrum of Cu2+@1a was monitored (Figure S14). In the XPS spectrum, the peak at 933.16 eV can be ascribed to Cu2+ 2p3. The XRD pattern and IR curve for Cu2+@1a showed peaks similar to those of 1a, suggesting that the main framework remains in its original structure even after metal-ion immobilization in aqueous solution (Figures S15 and S16). As for the reason for the quenching by Cu2+, we speculate that it might be attributed to the fact that Cu2+ can rapidly diffuse into the adaptable channels or interlayer of 1a and be recognized by the terminal Lewis basic sites and/or the carboxylate group. The interaction between the Cu2+ ions and ligands minimizes the energy-transfer efficiency, thus decreasing the luminescent intensity.
elements.clean_text: In order to understand the luminescence quenching process of 1a toward Cu2+, 1a was immersed in a M(NO3) n  or MCl2 aqueous solution to prepare the incorporated product M n+@1a. It was observed that the addition of 1a to the solutions of metal ions resulted in a visible color change of the solution for Cu2+. No such visible color change was observed upon the addition of 1a to other metal-ion solutions (d). In addition, the pictures of Cu2+@1a showed the incorporation of Cu2+ and rendered a color change of 1a from orange to green. These results indicate that 1a displays unique colors upon metal-ion encapsulation and can be considered as a universal naked-eye detector for Cu2+. The inductively coupled plasma results of the solid-state Cu2+@1a clearly indicated that the Cu2+ ion was immobilized in 1a, and the ratio of Cu and Eu for Cu2+@1a after immersion in the Cu2+ aqueous solution is 1:5.5. The corresponding energy-dispersive spectroscopy also verified the encapsulation of Cu2+ in 1a (Figure S13). The X-ray photoelectron spectrometry (XPS) spectrum of Cu2+@1a was monitored (Figure S14). In the XPS spectrum, the peak at 933.16 eV can be ascribed to Cu2+ 2p3. The XRD pattern and IR curve for Cu2+@1a showed peaks similar to those of 1a, suggesting that the main framework remains in its original structure even after metal-ion immobilization in aqueous solution (Figures S15 and S16). As for the reason for the quenching by Cu2+, we speculate that it might be attributed to the fact that Cu2+ can rapidly diffuse into the adaptable channels or interlayer of 1a and be recognized by the terminal Lewis basic sites and/or the carboxylate group. The interaction between the Cu2+ ions and ligands minimizes the energy-transfer efficiency, thus decreasing the luminescent intensity.

elements.content: The efficient removal of dyes from contaminated water before discharge into natural bodies is extremely important. In order to demonstrate the accessibility for larger molecules of 1a, dye-adsorption experiments were performed using 1a with four classical dyes with different sizes and charges (crystal violet, rhodamine B, methyl blue, and methylene blue) in aqueous solutions (Figure S17). As shown in Figure S18, 1a exhibited different adsorption abilities toward different organic dyes. Methylene blue was efficiently absorbed over a period of time, with the blue solution fading to light blue and the orange crystalline sample gradually becoming green. The purple solution of crystal violet faded to light purple, while the appearance of the orange crystals 1a became brown. The adsorptive capacity of 1a for rhodamine B was very weak, and the rhodamine B concentration in water decreased slightly. On the contrary, methyl blue cannot be effectively absorbed during the same process because the size of methyl blue is much larger than the largest aperture of the cages. We also determine the effect of the initial pH on the adsorption capacity of methylene blue and crystal violet. The results revealed that 1a could work effectively over a wide pH range and a favorable adsorption in a neutral environment, which is beneficial to the practical application of 1a (Figure S19). The concentration of the dyes in the desorbed solutions was also measured (Figures S20 and S21). As expected, the release of dyes can be realized in methanol. Selective removal of the targeted dyes is more attractive and challenging in the research fields of adsorption and separation. To confirm whether 1a can be employed to separate dye molecules with different size, the mixed binary dye solution was prepared to determine the selective adsorption capacity of 1a. The crystalline samples of 1a were placed in the mixed methylene blue/rhodamine B and crystal violet/methyl blue solutions, and the characteristic methylene blue and crystal violet peaks decreased drastically. Meanwhile, the absorption peaks of rhodamine B and methyl blue decreased slightly (Figure S22). Because of the molecular size of rhodamine B and methyl blue, the adsorption capacity for these two dyes is not as good as that for methylene blue and crystal violet. We can also speculate that there would be strong noncovalent host–guest interactions such as π–π interactions and hydrogen bonds between the framework and the dyes outside the framework because methylene blue and crystal violet possess two relatively short molecular dimensions. We can also see the color changes of the mixed solution in the adsorption process, as shown in Figure S23. This result clearly indicates that 1a could effectively and selectively adsorb dye molecules based on the size-exclusion effect, which means that it can be applied in the adsorptive removal and water treatment.

elements.content: In summary, a novel 3D lanthanide MOF, {[Eu2(abtc)1.5(H2O)3­(DMA)]·H2O·DMA} n (1), has been synthesized. The luminescent sensing studies indicate that 1a may be used as a bifunctional luminescent probe for detecting benzaldehyde and Cu2+ ions. What is more, 1a is a promising material for size-dependent dye molecular capture, which is very significant for environmental cleanup.
elements.clean_text: In summary, a novel 3D lanthanide MOF, {[Eu2(abtc)1.5(H2O)3(DMA)]⋅H2O⋅DMA} n  (1), has been synthesized. The luminescent sensing studies indicate that 1a may be used as a bifunctional luminescent probe for detecting benzaldehyde and Cu2+ ions. What is  more, 1a is a promising material for size-dependent dye molecular capture, which is very significant for environmental cleanup.

cln_elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction (XRD) analyses reveal that 1 crystallizes in the triclinic crystal system with the P1̅ space group and features a three-dimensional (3D) coordination framework (Table S1). The asymmetric unit of 1 contains two crystallographically unique Eu3+ ions, one and a half of the abtc4– ligand, three coordinated water molecules, one coordinated DMA molecule, one free DMA molecule, and one lattice water molecule. It is interesting to note that there are two types of Eu3+ ion environments in 1 (a). Eu1 is eight-coordinated and surrounded by five carboxylate O atoms from four different ligands and three coordinated water molecules. Eu2 is eight-coordinated and surrounded by seven O atoms from six ligands and one DMA molecule. All O–Eu–O bond angles and Eu–O bond lengths are within the expected ranges. In compound 1, abtc4– adopts different coordination modes, as shown in Scheme S1. A topological approach was employed to obtain better insight into this intricate 3D framework; such a 3D network represents a rare net topology with the Schläfli symbol of {413·62}2{414·67}2{420·614·811}­{414·6}2 (d). Removal of the guest molecules reveals that the free volume of 1 is 22.5% of the crystal volume, as calculated by PLATON analysis.

metadata.title:
Multifunctional
Three-Dimensional Europium Metal–Organic Framework for Luminescence
Sensing of Benzaldehyde and Cu2+ and Selective Capture
of Dye Molecules
